reviewText: As stated in the previous review, the "Bosko Video" logo that pops up during each of these 28 cartoons is so tacky that it renders the whole affair worthless.  Might as well wait for them to be shown on  television and record them.  Definitely not for collectors.  Bosko belongs  in the VHS market.
summary: "Bosko Video" logo ruins an otherwise great DVD.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Would you buy a DVD if you knew there was a big scratch across it?Probably not.IMO, this is just as bad.....The on-screen logo, which is commonly (and rightfully) referred to as a "bug," is nothing less than an ADVERTISEMENT....and it's an "in-your-face" advertisement, at that-- one that you can't get around.If you like logos on your products, that's your business, but quite frankly, I cannot understand why any reasonably intelligent person will plunk down their hard-earned cash to pay for some company's advertising.BTW, if you purchased this DVD without any knowledge of the "bug,",opened it and then discovered the on-screen advertising logo,you CAN STILL RETURN IT to Amazon,BUT DO IT FAST-- Don't wait for a month.Make sure you TELL AMAZON that you won't pay for on-screen advertising.
summary: the LOGO is an ADVERTISEMENT, folks.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Yes, there are some transfer problems (mostly cropped images) but the historical value of these cartoons, as well as their comedic value, is immense, and I for one am more than willing to overlook the technical glitches.  There's also a lot of surprisingly raunchy humor (since these cartoons were made for adult soldiers, not little kiddies...) and fans of risque or censored art will find a lot to enjoy here.  It's a great glimpse into the concerns of the time -- presented by some of the greatest animators of the WWII era.BTW - I think the featured review, written by Michael Phillips, may not be written about this DVD... It goes on at great length about sound problems and navigational glitches that I didn't experience while viewing this collection.  He also refers to a cartoon that is not included in this collection... So, it may be a bad review that was written for another product altogether.  Anyway, I'd take the negative comments about this disc with a grain of salt... There are problems with the disc, but they shouldn't ruin your fun while watching these great, long-lost cartoons.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The sad fact is that this is probably the best Private SNAFU collection  that there ever will be.  The Powers-That-Be in our government and at WB never intended for these films to be seen by the public and the film elements simply were not taken very well care of as a consequence.  Most of the shorts are in fair to good condition with  a few almost approaching excellent shape.  No question there are scratches on the film and occasional hissing on the soundtracks, but would do you expect for 60+ year-old films that weren't kept under the best archival conditions?Those facts aside, it is still a fine collection of War Era cartoons and a very funny one at that.  The bawdiness in these shorts doesn't even begin to approach the typical South Park episode so the collection is probably safe for anybody over 15.  As for those who are younger, let the parents beware and use their best judgment when youngsters are around.  As it is, I think most of the humor will go over the heads of kids younger than 10.Yes, some of these shorts have appeared as extras on the Looney Tunes Collections on DVD and the older Golden Age of Looney Tunes laserdiscs but even the Warners' releases of the SNAFU shorts really aren't in better shape than the copies presented on the SNAFU DVD set released by Bosko Video.Enjoy folks and stop b**ching about things that can't be changed.  At least these shorts still exist...  Unlike the vast majority of silent films made before 1930..
summary: The best collection of SNAFU to  get...

reviewText: I'm going to keep this review very brief. The cartoons on this DVD are pretty good. However, these cartoons are covered up by a "Bosko Video" logo. In my opinion, this logo ruins the DVD.
summary: The makers of this DVD have deliberately ruined it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: These wartime instructional cartoons had a rough job.  They were to train soldiers without being boring. To do this they used the Animation Team at Warner Bros. Studios. They created a soldier named Private SNAFU (Situation Normal All F***ed Up!). After the misadventures of this loser, the hope was that the real soldiers watching would do things the opposite way. Some of these cartoons have been released before and many on Cartoon collection DVDs.  But this is the entire series, for the first time.  It is vastly entertaining, instructive and a very good window into the manners of that long-ago time (over 68 years).  I recommend this DVD.  The transfers are good and the content still funny. - James B. Wiser
Title: N/A

reviewText: SNAFU - For those into history and those who like early animation this is a fun trip back in the "Wayback Machine".  Not the most entertaining but by far it was meant to be informative to the general enlisted population.  Many with just a 6th grade education.  So, keeping this in mind enjoy the works of Dr. Suess and Mel Blanc before they word household names.  Thats all folks!
Title: N/A

reviewText: These cartoons are part of war memoribilia and gave soldiers something to laugh at when they were being shot at. However, the quality of these transfers is horrible. Instead of being cropped properly and resized, they meerly blotted out alot around the edges. And the logo..please...DO NOT buy this collection, wait until someone does a proper release

reviewText: Yes, the Bosko logo is distracting and unnecessary. Worse is the terrible matte job, especially in part 1, the upper and right portion of the image is cut off, yet there is room on screen for the grey border in the lower and left sides. THAT is annoying! However, the content more than makes up for those problems IMHO.
